title: tories workington man red wall
story: Wakefield, Warrington, Keighley, Dewsbury and Barrow — rugby league towns brimming with working-class pride — are now represented by the Conservatives, carried by the swing voter that framed the election, Workington Man.Like Worcester Woman in Tony Blair’s  landslide, Workington Man was the key swing voter in last Thursday’s election.This imagined voter is a typically white, male, older Leave voter who didn’t go to university and lives in a town in the North or Midlands.Under David Cameron, fewer than half supported the Conservatives. Last week, nearly eight in ten backed Boris Johnson. Just  per cent of Workington Men voted for Jeremy Corbyn, and nine in ten believed Boris would make a better Prime Minister.In backing Boris and Brexit, these voters have made the Conservative Party far more representative of working Britain. More than a third of Conservative voters are now manual or skilled workers, and more than two thirds did not go to university.Geographically, the Tories now hold three times as many seats in the North East as they did historically, as well as three quarters of constituencies in the West Midlands, up from just one in four in . So much for the party of the South, the rich and the privileged.But this new electoral coalition will demand a new kind of politics. The common ground of public opinion is now marginally to the left on the economy and right on culture.By a ratio of two to one, voters want a society focused on giving people more security rather than freedom, and investment in public services rather than income tax cuts.If Boris wants to keep Workington Man blue he must break free of the traditional conservative economic playbook of trickle-down growth and bring purpose back to towns in the North and Midlands.It is telling that the walls of Workington train station are adorned with posters of the local British Steel factory that closed in , after  years of continuous production. This is a town proud of its history.The Conservatives must help Workington identy its economic future.New infrastructure, including better roads, reliable trains and faster broadband, will help. But on their own they will not be enough. For towns such as these to flourish, they need skilled jobs, dynamic companies and lasting private-sector investment.Margaret Thatcher bent over backwards to bring Nissan to Sunderland, revitalising the region and jump-starting a lagging national industry.Boris Johnson should do the same, using science, research  development and skills spending to tempt world-class companies in emerging sectors such as renewable energy and advanced manufacturing to cluster in his party’s new heartlands.High-skill jobs need skilled workers to do them — making a retraining revolution essential.More than a third of Workington Man voters have an apprenticeship and another third are educated to GCSE level. They are highly vulnerable to automation and globalisation.The Conservative manesto included £million a year to retrain disadvantaged people, but Onward’s analysis suggests more than £billion is needed each year to retrain Britain’s .million low-skilled workers before automation hits.The Tories must also reflect on the social fabric of the places it now represents.In many regional towns, the high street is emptying, libraries, pubs and social clubs are closing and crime is a rising concern.Places such as Wrexham, Blyth Valley and Bishop Auckland, all of which voted Conservative for the first time last week, are not in the lowest ranks of deprivation but they are united by a shared loss of belonging. The Conservatives need an answer to this fraying public realm.There is a limit to how much Whitehall can ever repair a sense of community itself, so a good start would be putting people and places back in control.The success of city mayors shows the value of local accountability for local services — as Boris Johnson, a former Mayor of London, knows well.Every place should be able to take the local leadership that the capital enjoyed during his tenure.Local groups should be given powers to take over shops, post offices and pubs when they close, with funding to match. More people should be encouraged to live and work near to where they grow up, rather than moving to the city to make their way.For too long, social success has been defined by how far you move from your parents.The realignment witnessed last week was profound, but it is not yet permanent.More than a fth of voters engaged in contract voting, lending their support to a party other than the one that represents their values — and contract voting was strongest in Leave seats and former Labour strongholds that fell to the Conservatives.Workington Man lent his vote. To make him vote blue again, the Tories need to deliver. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: snp mp insults the queen by crossing his fingers while swearing oath to her
story: Steven Bonnar crossed the fore and middle fingers as he held up his right hand while being sworn in as an MP today.All MPs are legally required to make the pledge, during which they swear allegiance to Queen Elizabeth II, her heirs and successors.The new member for Coatbridge, Chryston and Bellshill then appeared to make a subtle republican statement during the event.He later tweeted a screengrab from the dramatic pledge, but had appeared to have cropped out his hand.Mr Bonnar tweeted: Thats us all official now. I have been sworn in as the MP for Coatbridge Chryston and Bellshill.I look forward to serving all constituents to the best of my ability for the time Scotland remains within the UK.He made no mention of the monarchy or crossing his fingers in the social media post.Tory MP Andrew Bridgen accused him of insulting the queen.He told the Sun Online: There are very few actions of the SNP MPs that would shock me, so I can’t say it comes as a surprise, but I am sure they think it’s being very very clever.It’s insulting to the Queen, it’s insulting to parliament, but the SNP hold very little value for the institution of the House of Commons.Twitter users acted angrily to the image, with one demanding answers from both him and the SNP.They said: Just a simple question @StevenBonnarSNP what possessed you to cross your fingers whilst affirming your lawful oath to serve @theSNP and members of your Constituency  We need this to be addressed with a public statement.Another added: Fingers crossed smart a**e, I would judge my friends from Bellshill will be well pleased. Enjoy your  years.In  Labours Richard Burgon used a very similar form of words to register his protest.He made it clear he was being forced to swear allegiance to the British monarch.

title: married former beauty queen snapchatting
story: Ramsey BethAnn Bearse, , admitted sending the pics, but claimed they were meant for her husband.The former Miss Kentucky, who has been sacked from her teaching job, told a court she continued to sext the boy as she was afraid not to appease him.Bearse, from Charleston in West Virginia, now faces up to  years in jail.The boy also sent naked snaps of himself to her between August and October .Bearse was arrested and charged a short time later.She said: Since I am the adult, and he was just a teenager, it is my fault, and I accept full blame for the situation.So that’s how I’m guilty of this crime. I messed up big-time.She is due to be sentenced next month and could be caged for  years.Bearse also faces  years on probation and may be put on the sex offenders’ register for le.She has been axed as an eighth-grade science teacher at Andrew Jackson Middle School in Cross Lanes, West Virginia.Bearse was named Miss Kentucky in , playing bluegrass music to judges.She admitted possessing material depicting minors in sexually explicit conduct.

title: young footballer 100k scratchcard secret santa
story: Reece, , thought hed hit the jackpot after a pal at Lancashire Pro Direct Academy bought him nine scratchcards for Secret Santa.But the card showing hed won £k was a fake, leaving him devastated.A hilarious video captured the moment he found out hed been duped by his friend Charlie, .Reece told LadBible: I was gassed out my head [when I thought Id won] I was thinking of all the things I could buy.I was going to go and get new clothes. Im angry because I didnt get the money. No £k.He added: I won a quid on the other scratchcards, then I went to the shop and got another scratchcard, and I was one off another £k.Footage shows Reece scratching off the cards on a table as his teammates giggle.When he scratches his winning card he gets to his feet and says: Oh my god, Ive just won k.His pals, who are in on the joke, pretend to be shocked as Reece shows the winning scratchcard to a teammate.Reece tells his mates again I swear Ive just won k before shaking hands with a friend.One friend jokes thats  grand for me, mate.But Reece becomes suspicious, saying: Is this a fake or something. It has to be fake.A friend then reads to him from the joke cardyou have to be in possession of a real scratch card to play before Reece chucks it away in disgust.His pals continues mocking him as the disappointed lad realises hes been hoodwinked.Charlie said: I bought them [the scratchcards] for him, I knew hed fall for it. I bought him some real ones as well so it made it more realistic.There was nine in the whole thing, but there was one fake one in there.He was really happy because he hadnt won anything, he started standing up and going around saying that hed won  grand and everything.Then, someone said how do you claim it and he looked on the back and it said you must be in possession of a real scratchcard.You can just see his face drop as he throws it away.Reeve vowed somehow Ill get him back.Their coach, former Everton footballer Jamie Milligan, said: We were doing a Secret Santa between all of the lads, and one of them just got really badly stitched up.The reaction was pretty priceless. Everybody knew apart from Reece. He was devastated to be fair, but he took it well though.You can imagine the change in attitude when you think youve won  grand to - well - not.Hes one of the biggest stitch-ups anyway, so he had it coming...Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: heroic boy 3 rides toy car on busy road to find help for sick father
story: Stefan Snowden covered a quarter of a mile on his favourite toy before being saved by two stunned locals.After he was plucked from the busy A near Bourne, Lincs, the little lad told his rescuers: “Daddy was poorly.”Stefan’s home is on a quiet lane, so he had travelled more than  yards before reaching the A.Shocked motorists were forced to drive around him until an unnamed woman who lives near the road rushed into the traffic, stopped cars and swooped the lad into her arms.Another local woman then took him into her home where they tried to work out where he had come from and called police. One witness said: “The little boy was just trundling along the main road towards Bourne.“There were three or four cars behind him, but he was so low that another impatient motorist overtook the line of traffic.“Then a woman stopped her van and parked it across the road to rescue him. She was very brave.”Mum Carla Neve, , had popped out of the house for a few minutes to see a friend. She told how Stefan set off from the family’s home in the village of Twenty after former factory worker Marc, , suffered a seizure on the sofa.She said: “Marc suffers from epilepsy and they have changed his medication.“He was on the sofa and loses consciousness when he has a seizure.“Stefan knows how to get out of the front door and must have gone to get his truck. He loves his little Paw Patrol truck. Stefan was definitely going for help.“We live on a very quiet lane, and he uses his feet to push it along. It is quite a distance to the end of the lane where it meets the main road.“When we spoke to the police Stefan said ‘Daddy was poorly’.“We are so proud of him and grateful to the two ladies.Marc recovered from the seizure. He said: “I am thankful to my son, going for help. He is amazing.”Inspector Rachel Blackwell, of Lincs Police, said: “We have so much praise for the speedy and brave actions of the first passer-by who put herself at risk to stop a tragedy happening to this child.“Without her speedy actions the child could have been seriously injured or worse.“The action of the second woman who opened her home and provided a safe environment was amazing.“She entertained the boy while the first woman tried to track his family down.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eight year old influencer ryan top earning youtuber
story: The youngster, Ryan, of the RyansWorld YouTube channel nabbeded the top spot, with Dude Perfect and Nastya coming in second and third respectively.Between them, the top ten earners rake in a combined  million .The Dude Perfect channel, coming in second documents the exploits of a group of toy obsessed thirty-somethings attempting ious trick shots with Nerf guns.And the Nastya channel, taking third place, follows the blog of Russian Anastasia Radzinskaya who has cerebral palsy.According to researchers, YouTube channels with kids are more likely to gain viewers.Little Ryan uploads around one toy review a day to his . million subscribers.Megastar Ryan and his family, who live in the US, started up the channel in March .Then aged just four, Ryan was a big fan of toy-review videos and asked his mum and dadhe could post his own clips on YouTube.It’s since grown into an empire, branching out into spin-off channels, digital characters and the odd food review.The youngster also topped the list last year, at the time he told NBC he was so popular because people thought he was funny.The only Brit to make the list was gamer, Dan TDM - coming in ninth, five places down from last year.This years list saw Logan Paul - hounded by controversy after filming the body of an apparent suicide victim in a Japanese forest - drop off the list completely, along with brother, Jake who came in second last year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour mp calls colleagues c word
story: Leftwinger Lloyd Russell-Moyle accused other Labour MPs furious with the Opposition boss of acting out of ulterior motives.Instead of accepting any personal blame for Jeremy Corbyn or his failed manesto, the Brighton MP instead insisted Labour lost the election because the party and its MPs didn’t fight hard enough.Mr Russell-Moyle declared: “Fighting spirit is what we need. It’s what we lacked in the election”.The explosive remarks came in an exchange with a Labour colleague on Facebook messenger, which has been leaked to The Sun.Asked by the colleague why he wasn’t joining calls for Mr Corbyn to resign, Mr Russell-Moyle declared: “Because I’m not a c*** like those calling for his immediate resignation”.The firebrand MP added: “All the people saying stand down immediately are not saying it in good faith and that’s reason enough to ignore.“Anyonesays that they knew exactly what was wrong I’m afraid is a liar and a charlatan, and I will take no lessons from people who have spent the time undermining the party in all sorts of manners ofthe last few years”.In the conversation, Mr Russell-Moyle also stuck the kne into moderate Labour MP and potential leadership contender Jess Phillips, a long-standing Corbyn critic.Referring also to veteran Labour MP John Spellar, he added: “Jess Phillips would be a disaster. I think she would be truly terrible. I would have anyone but Jess. Well, maybe not anyone – Spellerwould be worse”.When contacted by The Sun last night about his attack on other Labour MPs and the use of his language, Mr Russell-Moyle said: “I said that because calling for Jeremy to go now is a silly and I would go so far to say c***ish thing to say.The best thing is for Jeremy Corbyn is to move aside in an orderly and organised fashion.“In private communications, it is an acceptable word to use, in public though it wouldn’t be.”He also accused the person who leaked the messages to be a suspended member of the party.Mr Russell-Moyle added: “People were speaking with knee jerk reactions the day after the election. title: labour hope munchkins momentum power
story: Let’s all sign up and vote for someone who’ll keep them out of power for the next decade or two.I say two quid. It’s moreyou’re working. But just tell them you’re unemployed or a student. They won’t check. Most of their current members are one or the other.And look who you have to choose from! Such a rich tapestry of political brilliance.David Lammy! Yay! The man who hates the police stop and search policy. A man who will brand you a racist before you’ve even opened your mouth.Richard Burgon! A plank of wood into which a village idiot has drilled two eyes and a mouth. Rebecca Long-Bailey — so inept even her own party members refer to her as Rebecca Wrong Daily.We could even co-ordinate and demand that they keep Magic Grandpa as boss. I mean, the party still seems to be in a state of denial. It was nothing to do with Corbyn! The voters loved him and loved our policies! We only didn’t win because of, er, Tory lies. The voters are thick, you see. Oh — and Brexit.For a very long time I was a member of the Labour Party. The main reason I left is the main reason nobody voted for it this time around. It is no longer the party of the poor and the working class.It has become a fringe group for metropolitan, middle-class liberals.Look at the only places it did well. Cambridge, Putney, Canterbury. Ha, bring on the revolution, then.“Are we manning the barricades, Cressida  Can I finish my Yakult first ”In a sense it doesn’t really matter who wins their leadership race. Labour lost not just because of the idiotic Corbyn or because of Brexit. It goes far deeper than that.It is the culture of the party. It despises everything its old voter base stands for. Even the moderates.It cannot abide patriotism, for a start. Its old voters are rather proud of Britain, and what Britain stands for. Corbyn and his allies hate our country.The traditional Labour voters believe in the traditional family, too. They have no time for identity politics and political correctness. They want a better deal, but don’t buy into all of the infantile agit-prop that goes along with today’s Labour Party.How the hell do you change that when the far-Left munchkins of Momentum still hold all the power There are still good people in the Labour Party. Some of them — like the brilliant Caroline Flint — lost their seats last week because of what Labour has become.Look at it now. Corbyn is STILL the leader. There is nothing they can do to get rid of him. He’s called for a period of reflection. It didn’t take the voters very long to reflect, did it We need a new party which represents working class people, especially away from London. That’s why I joined the Social Democratic Party.And we can happily leave the Labour Party to its “reflections”. Its support for terrorists, its loathing of the West. It STILL thinks it got its policies right.Even with a new leader it will still be terminally deluded.SO, is the BBC biased Welsh gob on a stick Huw Edwards thinks it is impeccably neutral. But then he would, wouldn’t he  But don’t take my word for it.Here’s the brilliant ex BBC journo and newsreader Michael Buerk, writing in the magazine The Critic. “ . . . all the presenters on the Today programme have been privately educated, like an astonishingly high proportion of the BBC’s editorial and production staff.”He added: “These are unormly bright, urban, young, well-educated arts graduates who have moved smoothly from one liberal institution to another. With little understanding of, or sympathy for, industry, business, the countryside or of course Brexiteers.”As Buerk pointed out, the BBC’s worldview is formed by the people who work for it.An estimated  per cent of them were against Brexit and there are plenty of objective studies which bear out a huge bias against Brexit.Go get ’em, BoJo.The advice is to always park where there are lots of people nearby .And in a well lit area. With the back of the car as close to a fence or kerb as possible.Anyway,someone sidles up to you in the pub and offers you a catalytic converter for a ton, here’s what to do.Kick him in the penkies and shove the converter as far up his rectum as is humanly possible.He’ll be passing incredibly clean wind, regardless of how many sprouts he eats.IS it possible to be more thick than Lauren Goodger  If so, how The Towie “star” got caught in a sting by the BBC. She was filmed endorsing a supposed health drink called Cyanora.She was told the product contained hydrogen cyanide, one of the most lethal substances known to mankind. But not known to Lauren, apparently.She was perfectly happy to give it her blessing. She admitted she’d never tried it . But then she also admitted she had never tried another product she had endorsed.Listen. Never believe TV personalities, actors, singers, etc.Don’t believe them when they tell you what way to vote. Don’t believe them when they’re trying to flog you something. For the most part they’re just greedy and thick as a plate of mince.OH what a pleasure it was to walk around a nice liberal, middle-class area of London last weekend singing: “Ohhhhhh Jeremy Corbyn!”The looks of hatred! I suppose it’s wrong to take pleasure in other people’s misery. But sometimes I can’t help it. Years of being told we’re all bigoted, racist and uneducated, I suppose.My we said she was more thrilled by the election result than she was by the birth of our daughter, which I think is pushing it a bit.Anyway, Boris Johnson has proven that he is a very canny politician indeed.He won the Mayor of London elections twice – by wooing the most right-on liberal electorate in Europe. And then he appealed to exactly the opposite tranche of voters to win the election last week.Huge credit, mind, to his adviser Dominic Cummings. A very sharp bloke – and from the North East. He never had any doubts about the result.What, being called a “smarty-pants”  If you end up troubled by having been called something like that  years previously, I would argue that your problems lie a lot deeper and were not actually caused by the insult.Shouldn’t we be trying to instil a degree of resilience among you people  Rather than feeling “triggered” at every single thing that’s said to them TURKEY is rapidly becoming the pariah state of the world.Its horrible government allows the genocidal terrorists Hamas to plot attacks on Israel from within Istanbul.The Turkish leader, Recep Erdogan, recently rolled out the red carpet for the Islamist maniacs of Hamas.A few years ago we were anxious to welcome Turkey into the European Union.Now we should impose sanctions on the country.Friends of anti-Jewish terrorists are no friends of ours.CHRISTMAS is the time of year when you open a bottle from the fridge expecting a nice glass of wine and it’s actually the we’s non-alcoholic “Christmas Mulled Berry Punch”, which tastes like a Moroccan’s gusset.The time of year when the rellies turn up, like not very wise men, each bearing their present of a bloody panettone which nobody anywhere will eat.When the awful Lonely This Christmas, by Mud, gets dragged out of its tomb – I’ve hated that song for  years.When good, God-fearing Christian people kick the s**t out of each other in an attempt to secure the last PlayStation, or something, in the sales. Ah well. There are compensations, I suppose.Half a day off work spent with a bottle of Jack Daniel’s and some Mon Cheri liqueurs in my tightly locked office watching a rerun of Millwall beating Arsenal at Highbury in . Can’t top that.It’s been a helluva year – hope you all have a lovely Christmas Day and get all that you wished for. x Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun readers generosity ira john downey
story: It has taken  long years for his ­victims’ determined relatives to get the justice denied to them in the criminal courts by Tony Blair’s Government giving Downey immunity.But it took our readers’ generosity to fund the case after Legal Aid chiefs initially refused.We congratulate the families and hope they now take Downey for every penny he has in damages.And today there will be further good news for those who fought for Britain in the Troubles — as well as their families: a new law at last ending vexatious prosecutions against veterans.For good measure, the Queen’s Speech will announce an end to early release for jailed terrorists too. Excellent.It’s asBritain has been engulfed by a sudden outbreak of common sense.EVEN in a crowded field of terrible options for new Labour leader, Keir Starmer stands out as a stone-cold loser.The man best known for his dismal failures as Director of Public Prosecutions and for talking Labour into its suicidal “people’s vote” strategy.Sir Keir, the multi-millionaire human rights QC now posing as a working-class boy.Only one alternative is LESS likely to win back working-class voters in the North: Emily Thornberry — Lady Nugee, to be formal — another sanctimonious Islington barrister who sneers at working people and marched to reverse their Brexit vote dressed as an EU flag.Labour would be insane to pick either. Especially now we know the election result flattered Corbyn.The boundaries are still skewed in Labour’s favour — and the Brexit Party seems to have gted Corbyn  northern seats by ­preventing certain Tory victories.Labour’s problems run far deeper than they have realised. That’s without picking smug, rich London Remainers as leader.A PLEA to our new Government: go with the evidence. There is no proof sugar taxes work. Don’t even think about more of them.Boris Johnson is clearly no fan of the fizzy drinks levy his predecessors were persuaded to impose. Health Secretary Matt Hancock must not buckle to the same nanny state health lobbyists.Such taxes can only be justiedthey cut obesity. There’s no evidence of that anywhere. Nor will there be, no matter how many milkshakes you add them to. They just make shopping pricier for all.The Tories should use their powerful new mandate to build more sports facilities or boost children’s education about the value of healthy eating and exercise.Not to ramp up taxes with no provable benefit to public health. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we must stop letting violent offenders like ewan ireland out with no restrictions its plain madness
story: Tony Blair’s infamous Antisocial Behaviour Orders were supposed to stop troublemakers causing misery for the public but ended up being broken with impunity and worn as a badge of honour by their recipients.But you may not have heard the letters RUI, standing for Released Under Investigation.If not, you soon will be hearing about them. RUIs are what the Law Society’s head of justice has described as a “major scandal” waiting to erupt.I know Home Secretary Priti Patel will have a lot on her plate as Parliament begins, but this ought to be one of her top priorities.The shocking overuse of RUI came to light on Wednesday, after -year-old thug Ewan Ireland was jailed for le for the murder of solicitor Peter Duncan in a Newcastle shopping centre in August.Peter’s misfortune was to have brushed past Ireland in the doorway of a shop, an act which Ireland took as a slight.He took hold of the screwdriver he had stolen minutes earlier and drove it into Mr Duncan’s heart.It is a tale of mindless, casual violence which has become all too common in modern Britain as the jumped-up egos of young men rage against anyone who gets in their way.But what makes it all the more disturbing is that Ireland’s tendency for extreme violence was well known to police and the courts, yet still he was allowed to walk the streets.While other boys of his age are busy studying for A-levels, Ireland had already amassed a formidable range of criminal qualications.He had  convictions for  dferent offences. He was on conditional discharge for an offence of battery and on bail for a charge of affray for threatening to slash another boy’s Achilles’ tendon.Yet in spite of all this, he had been released under investigation for a robbery.He is not the only violent criminal to have been sent on his way by police. In September last year Alan Martin, of Sunderland, was released by police after his estranged we accused him of raping her.Not only did officers release him, they also ed to him the keys to his we’s house. He promptly ed to the address, attacked her with a hammer and strangled her before taking his own le, too.Astonishingly, Northumbria Police were later cleared by the Independent Office for Police Conduct. No one seems to want to take responsibility. No doubt it will be the same next time, too.Since April , , violent criminals have been released under investigation, Home Office figures reveal.Unlike police bail, no restrictions have been placed on these people. They are not banned from visiting particular places, they have not had to raise a deposit, hand over their passport or report to police at regular intervals. Nor, unlike police bail, is there any time limit on RUI, so police are under no pressure to bring charges quickly.The misuse of RUI is a hangover from Amber Rudd’s time as Home Secretary. It was her Policing and Crime Act  which stopped police putting people on bail for periods of more than  days. True, something needed to be done. The case of former Radio  DJ Paul Gambaccini had inspired the rule change.He had been held on bail for a whole year as police investigated accusations of historic sex offences which turned out to be without foundation.Unable to put criminals on bail for more than  days, police forces took to releasing them under investigation instead.That might be perfectly reasonable in the case of relatively minor crimes which take a long time to investigate, but it is hardly an appropriate way to treat suspected murderers and rapists, especially those with a long history of violent offences.At the very least, people suspected of violent offences — and for which good evidence exists that those offences really did take place — need to be monitored.As for people who have been released on licence while serving sentences for previous convictions, there should be no argument at all — they should be taken back to prison without hesitation.Ministers like to talk tough on crime, especially around election time, but behind the scenes they get caught in the stranglehold of the liberal establishment.Punishments get weakened, prisoners get released early.Disgracefully, former Home Secretary Jack Straw described the sentencing system as the “benign deception of the public”, who, unaware of the soft reality, assume that criminals are being properly punished.But there is nothing benign about serial offenders being freed to rape and murder when police and the courts know full well their records.During the election campaign, Boris Johnson finally called an end to the deception.Braving an onslaught from the nation’s liberal consciences, he announced that prisoners will no longer be eligible for automatic early release — something which allowed the London Bridge killer Usman Khan to embark on his murderous spree.But the Johnson Government should not end there.It needs to stop the police releasing violent offenders back into the community without any restrictions on their movements nor any requirement ever to report to a police station.Liberals like to say that we can’t solve crime just by jailing people. On the contrary, had Ewan Ireland been kept out of circulation after his first offence it would alone have meant  fewer crimes in Newcastle over the past four years.It is hard enough to catch criminals.But to release those we do catch, giving them the freedom to embark on long crime sprees, is plain madness.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new 133k homes welsh countryside hole
story: Built along the River Cynon on the edge of the Brecon Beacons and commuting distance from Cardf, the new houses look perfect for first-time buyers or a small family. However there is one small problem.Andrea Lacey snapped a gaping hole forming just  metres away from a house on the Golwg Y Mynydddevelopment in Mountain Ash that seems to have someone already living in it.According to local authorities, the river has suffered from a deep scour, causing the bank to collapse.Locals have been reporting concerns about the houses being dangerously close to the collapsing riverbanks since July after trees were seen floating downriver.However the developers of the new red-brick estate say that the responsibility for the bank lies with the landowner.Developer Persimmon Homes East Wales is blaming work by others and has decided that no remedial work is required in spite of admitting that the bank has failed following an inspection on Tuesday.In spite of the pictures showing the garden fence of one of the houses dipping over the massive hole just a foot under it, no emergency work is being done to save the houses and their occupants.Rhondda Cynon Taf Council denies that the collapsed bank that they are responsible for is a threat to the development.A spokesman said: “The river wall in no way impacts upon the land or properties currently being developed by Permission Homes at Cwn Cynon.Natural Resources Wales told Wales Online that there has been no application from the developer to start working on the collapse.

title: moment horny couple caught romping top bus broad daylight
story: Caught on camera, the cheeky pair can be seen enjoying a steamy session at the back of the top deck of a bus travelling down Bury Old Road in Prestwich, Manchester.As gas engineer John Dolan sat in his van waiting for pals, he noticed movement in the corner of his eye.When he looked up from his phone, he spotted the strange sight - and quickly filmed the lusty couple before sending it to his we in shock.After realising the bus was heading in the direction of a local secondary school, he decided to post the video online to shame the disgusting couple.Filming from his car, John can be heard in fits of laughter as the bus drives past with the two riders on the top deck.As the bus rolls away, the pair get into full swing, seemingly unconcerned with the onlookers.John, from Manchester, said: It was mad - very strange. Its just wrong.It looked quite vigorous. They slowed down a bit when the bus stopped but were still at it, then carried on again as it pulled off.I cant imaginean old lady got on the bus and saw them. Shed probably have a heart attack.I just hope theyre a couple and not doing it on the sly because now theyve gone viral.He posted the video on Twitter with the caption: When your sat waiting for your scran and clock a couple riding on a Tuesday afternoon.John had initially sniggered at the display, before realising the road had at least three schools on it.John said: Theres a sandwich shop round the corner and I was waiting in the van for my mates to come out.The bus pulled in at the bus stop and I looked up from my phone because I saw movement and thought whats going on there There was another woman crossing the road at the time with a smirk on her face. She must have seen it because she looked about embarrassed.There are kids on that road. Theres a high school about a minute down the road and it was heading in that direction.I sent the video my we and she said thats disgusting. Obviously Im a lad and I find it funny.Twitter users reacted to the saucy video - which now has nearly half a million views.One user asked: What bus was that  before another quickly replied The  Another commented: Well within their rightstheyve bought their day rider tickets along with a picture of the bus ticket - highlighting the play on words.

title: reckless cyclist young child rides street helmet
story: The reckless man cycled down a narrow city-centre road lined with parked cars, holding the young child perched on his hip in Cotham Hill in Bristol.Towards the end of the video clip, a car can be seen pulling out of a parking bay on the other side of the narrow road, just as the man cycles past it.The man and young child wore matching orange jackets, but neither had a helmet on.One witness, , who did not wish to be named, said: I was thinking this cannot be for real.He was cycling one-handed and the kid didnt even have a helmet on a busy narrow road.The question is why  Why would you put your child in danger  Imaginehe was involved in an accident.He added: When my son was , he was cycling home from school and he came off his bike, cracking his helmet.That could have been his skull. Thats why I am always like, Wear a helmet for Gods sake.It is not mandatory for cyclists to wear a helmet, but it is illegal to carry a passenger on a bike unless it has been specially designed - but this bike doesnt seem to fit the description.The people of Bristol have blasted the man carrying the young child as irresponsible and said he was endangering the childs le.Nicholas Foxwell wrote on Facebook: As a keen cyclist I can hand on heart say that man should be in serious trouble for endangering a child and cycling without due care and attention.Its people like this that give us cyclist a bad name.And Terry Nichols added: What an irresponsible pillock. He should be prosecuted for dangerous riding and endangering the le of a minor.Meanwhile, Twitter user Red wrote: Incidents like this one make my blood boil - but very regrettably are typical of the uncaring, dangerous and often couldnt give a damn cycling community in Bristol.Jon Usher, head of partnerships at cycling charity Sustrans, said: The Highway Code is clear that passengers must not be carried on a cycle, unless it has been specically built or adapted to carry one.So family cycles, cargo cycles, or any cycle fitted with a child seat fit well within the law.We believe that it is a personal choice whether to wear a cycle helmet or not, and for parents to make that choice for their children.Parents should, of course, always ensure that their children are safe and feel safe when they are cycling together.

title: queen speech coat blue or green
story: Twitter users went wild as they discussed whether her outfit was green or blue, in a throwback to the infamous dress debate.Her Majesty arrived at the Houses of Parliament today to give the Queens Speech.She wore a classic royal coat and hat combo, as she walked in with the help of her son, Prince Charles.One person wrote: The Queen looks chuffed shes wearing blue.But another, seeing things dferently, tweeted: The Queen looks like the green triangle that no one eats at Christmas.Some were convinced the Queen wore green in a subtle message about the environment or the green party, but the outfit appeared Brexit blue to others.An eager viewer posted: I reckon Queen is in Brexit colours today Better than the royal blue hat with yellow flowers after Ref.The state occasion for the -year-old was signicantly trimmed down today, with the Queen arriving in a car rather than a carriage and without her traditional mounted escort of Household Cavalry.She snfed several times throughout - leading to speculation she could have a cold.It comes after celebs including Kim Kardashian, Kanye West and Taylor Swt joined the masses in a Twitter row – over the colour of a dress.An outfit sparked a huge online debate in , as it appears dferent to everyone who sees it.It became known simply as #TheDress on twitter and was picked up as the #blackandgold tribe and #whiteandgold team started the argument.The debate got messy. Taylor Swt saw blue and black, Anna Kendrick saw gold and white, and Kim Kardashian and Kanye West fought amongst themselves.Experts eventually tried to soothe the masses by explaining our brains intuitively try and discount dferent colour backgrounds to see the true colour.Those that discounted gold saw blue, and vice versa.The fight kicked off again over a recording of a man saying either Yanny or Laurel which first cropped up on reddit.#Yanny and #Laurel polls turned up all over social media, Ellen Degeneres weighed in, and everyone got upset.By Sasha OSullivanThousands of people see the dress as blue and black – including Justin Bieber – while to others, including actress Julianne Moore, it appears white and gold.Finally answers were given in a new study, neuroscientist Doctor Pascal Wallisch concludes that the dferences in perception are down to our assumptions about how the dress was illuminated.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tate modern boy recovery speaking christmas
story: The little lad has been bravely battling back to recovery since the horror attack in which Jonty Bravery, , threw him from the building in London in August.His family have now revealed in a post on a GoFundMe page that he is also regaining sensation in his limbs.The page has raised an eye-watering £, for the boys treatment and rehabilitation.The French youngster, who cannot be named due to his age, was attacked by autistic teenager Bravery at the tourist attraction on August .He left the youngster with a broken back, fractures to his limbs and a bleed on the brain.In the GoFundMe post, the family said: We have very good news to share with you. Our little knight begins to speak.He pronounces one syllable after another, not all of them, and most of the time we have to guess what he means but its better and better. Its a wonderful progress.The family added theof movement in his limbs has been a very painful experience for the child.They said: He also begins to move his four limbs now. It is very dficult to see it concerning his left arm and hand, but its really slowly beginning to move.However, as he begins to move, sensations come back and he feels more pain, above all during the night, which is very exhausting for everybody, but he is very courageous and we stay strong for him.In the message to generous supporters, the family thanked everyone who has contributed to the fund.The statement added: Your help makes it possible to offer our son the best rehabilitation, and for us to take care of our little boy everyday, to stay with him as long as he needs with the best doctors and therapists.Thank you also to keep us strong with all your kind messages. You cant imagine how much it is helpful.Bravery admitted a charge of attempted murder earlier in December at the Old Bailey in London and will be sentenced next February.After throwing the little lad from the building he approached a member of staff and said: I think Ive murdered someone, Ive just thrown someone off the balcony.When Bravery, from Ealing, West London, was arrested he told police he had travelled to the London gallery with the intention of hurting someone so he could be on the TV news that evening.He said: I wanted to be on the news, who I am and why I did it, so when it is official no-one can say anything .Bravery then said he heard voices tell him he had to hurt or kill people and wanted to prove a point to every idiot who said he didnt have mental health issues.Appearing via video link from Broadmoor Hospital at the Old Bailey, Bravery could be seen closing his eyes and speaking under his breath during the hearing.The victim, who was visiting the UK from France, was forced to spend two months in intensive care and left unable to speak or eat after the horror attack on August .His French mum and dad dubbed their son their “little knight” as they revealed previously he could only smile to communicate.CPS prosecutor Emma Jones said: This devastating and shocking incident at the Tate Modern on  August of this year changed the lives of Bravery’s young victim and his family forever.The boy was singled out by Bravery who threw him from the viewing  intending to kill him.That he survived the five storey fall was extraordinary.Eye witness accounts and CCTV footage, along with Bravery’s admissions at the time of the arrest that his actions were pre-planned, meant he had little choice but to accept responsibility for his actions. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: emily maitlis prince andrews interview
story: The Newsnight anchor grilled the Duke Of York over his relationship with his paedophile pal in last months interview, seen as a car crash for Andrew.Writing in , she described the disgraced Duke as unleashed during the -minute-long interview.When Ms Maitlis asked Andrew, ,he regretted his whole friendship with Epstein he replied: “Still not.Ms Maitlis wrote: It was such a candid admission, such a bald refusal to play the game with any wider apology or regret.It would become the pivotal moment of the entire hour. This is a man – a prince – who did not come to repent.He came to earn back his right to tell the story his way.During the bombshell interview Prince Andrew denied sleeping with Virginia Giuffre, one of Epsteins victims, on three separate occasions, twice while she was underage.He said one encounter in  didnt happen as he spent the day with his daughter Princess Beatrice, taking her to Pizza Express in Woking for a party.Ms Maitlis, who revealed the Newsnight interview was months in the making, said under-fire Andrew saw it as a chance to give his side of the story.She added: Andrew was unleashed. Unstoppable.After a decade of silent frustration, he wanted to tell me everything.He paused being “a royal” and found his voice.After the interview Andrew was charming, and even more relaxed, the BBC presenter said.Andrew was stripped of all royal duties shortly after it was broadcast.This week, The Sun revealed Andrew decided to miss his own daughter’s engagement party for “fear of embarrassment or abuse” from celebrity attendees.The Duke of York stayed away from the star-studded bash for Princess Beatrice, which was held in London.The party took place at showbiz hotspot Chiltern Firehouse to celebrate Beatrice’s engagement to property developer Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi, which was announced in September – just one month after Epstein was found dead in his prison cell.Celeb friends such as James Blunt, Pippa Middleton and Dexter Fletcher all attended.Andrew attended the Queen’s Christmas lunch on Wednesday with other senior members of the royal family, as well as a staff party at Buckingham Palace on Monday.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: raf officer squadron leader girlfriend
story: Flight Lieutenant Tim Barry, a -year-old helicopter pilot, put his hands around Sarah Seddons neck until she passed out on their bed while her three-year-old son slept in another room.Barry was cleared of attempted murder and grievous bodily harm with intent during a five-day trial last month.He admitted a lesser charge of assault and was today handed an  month community order.Judge Ian Pringle QC told him: [You] placed your hands around her neck, one of the most vulnerable parts of the human body.I cannot ignore that that is potentially very serious and a potential fatal attack.The court heard how the pilots, both based at RAF Benson in Oxfordshire at the time, had been celebrating Ms Seddonson a night out in Marlow, Bucks., before the incident in .Judge Pringle said several mitigating factors, including Barrys good character and risking your le on behalf of this country meant he could pass a community sentence.Barry, of Cuxham in Oxfordshire, remains in a relationship with Ms Seddon, .Oxford Crown Court heard that the couple were still an item but had had to spend almost two years apart communicating over Skype and by text messages, as the judge had previously made it a condition of his bail that he and Ms Seddon should not be together.She had asked for that condition to be scrapped, so they could live together.Seddon also refused to give evidence against her lover during the trial.Senior ranking Wing Commander James Maston - who sat through the six-day trial - told the jury he had known the defendant for ten years both personally and professionally, describing Barry as his best friend.He added: Whilst based overseas we are faced with dficult challenges.It is often not clear what you should do Tim would always give a measure opinion which was referenced by the RAF as he was promoted to head of his peer group at the time.The commander stated he knew Ms Seddon for  years and regarded them as a loved-up couple, referring to the assault on January  in  as utterly out of character.The defendant - who called himself a monster in his evidence - fell in love with his senior Squadron leader while they were serving in Afghanistan.Barry was so besotted, he gave up a role in his beloved squadron of  years so they could start a relationship.On Ms Seddon’s first weekend back from a three-month deployment overseas, the couple went for a celebratory night out.But their evening ended with Barry strangling his partner unconscious and calling  to say I tried to kill my girlfriend by strangulation.Defence lawyer Lisa Wilding told the jury: The prosecution paints a picture of a man who demands to be in control, but I suggest the evidence tells you he is a man who does not like to go to sleep on an argument.There is no evidence to suggest he was a controlling man, not a shred.But what you have heard from people who have known him for a decade is a man who puts others first.The man who is closest to him, RAF Wing commander James Maston, has never seen him aggressive and he is described by friends as one of the most kind and generous people they have ever met, an exemplary person and a complete gentleman.Barry was ordered to form better relationships and undertake rehabilitation courses as part of his sentence.He has been grounded by the RAF and is performing a dferent role within the force.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: where is theresa may is she conservative mp
story: She was forced to quit after her Brexit deal failed to win the backing of MPs – but what has she been up to since Mrs May announced she was resigning as Prime Minister in a tearful statement outside  Downing Street on May .She remained leader of the Conservative Party until June  and as a lame duck Prime Minister until July  when Boris Johnson took over.On July , Mrs May addressed the public, saying: I will continue to do all I can to serve the national interest, and play my part in making our United Kingdom a great country with a great future - a country that truly works for everyone.Since then she has largely kept out of the public eye and kept silent about her successor’s handling of Brexit.In her final days as PM, the cricket lover welcomed England’s victorious World Cup winning team to Downing Street.Mrs May is a backbench MP for Maidenhead and has been carrying out her duties for her constituency since resigning.Shortly after her election success it appeared Mrs May had buried the hatchet with her successor Boris Johnson.They were all smiles at a party for the newly elected Tory MPs, and were seen putting their dferences aside in a hug for the ages.She used her first day back as a backbench MP to take a trip to Lord’s to see England play  Ireland in a one-off test match.On September , Mrs May was snapped pointing at a pothole in her constituency with local councillor.On September , Mrs May was accused of rank hypocrisy as she sprayed gongs to an army of former cronies and aides in a ‘resignation honours’.Boris Johnson and Theresa May hug and make up to celebrate Tory winMrs May has been the MP for Maidenhead in Berkshire for the last  years.Despite the ignominy with which her time as Prime Minister ended, she remains popular with her constituents.At the last general election, she polled . per cent of the vote.She was reelected in the December General Election and polled at . per cent of the vote.Mrs May secured a , majority in her constituency.When a prime minister loses power they can either stay as an MP for their constituency or retire from politics altogether.When Gordon Brown resigned he wrote a book called Beyond the Crash about the  financial crisis.John Major started watching more cricket with this freetime.David Cameron published a memoir in May  about his time as the PM.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former Labour MP who sued a union for libel has won a High Court fight and been awarded £, damages. Anna Turley had sued Unite and blogger Stephen Walker, the owner of the left-wing Skwawkbox site, over what she called a politically-motivated attack. Ms Turley said a  article on Skwawkbox, which contained a press statement from Unite, libelled her by conveying the meaning that she had acted dishonestly when submitting an application to join the union. She also says Unite misused her private information. Unite bosses and Mr Walker fought the case and said Ms Turley had been dishonest and was not fit to be an MP. They said the article was true or justied in the public interest. But Mr Justice Nicklin, who oversaw a High Court trial in London in November, ruled today in favour of the former MP - who lost her seat in Redcar to the Tories last week. Unite is now planning to appeal the High Courtaposs judgement. Ms Turley had wanted more than £,. Ms Turley today accused the defendants of frankly appalling attempts at character assassination during the court case. And she accused Unite of a colossal waste of membersapos money by funding Skwawkboxaposs legal costs adding: I hope serious questions will be asked of the leadership of the Union by its members. She said: The judge himself concluded that ‘the Defendants’ conduct during the trial has seriously aggravated the harm to the Claimant’s reputation and her distress’. This has been an extremely stressful and unpleasant process, and one I never imagined I would be engaged in with a Trade Union. The article related to a Unite membership application Ms Turley made in December . Mr Justice Nicklin heard how Ms Turley had applied to be a Unite member under a Community membership category. He was told that Uniteaposs Community section was aimed at people not in paid employment and cost p a week. A barrister representing Unite said Ms Turley had been willing to conceal, mislead and deceive. Anthony Hudson QC said Ms Turley wanted to vote against Unite general secretary Len McCluskey in an election without being noticed and without the union knowing she was an MP. Ms Turley had links to a WhatsApp group of Labour MPs, known as the Birthday Club, who were opposed to Jeremy Corbynaposs leadership, the judge heard. Mr Hudson said her application flowed from a Birthday Club WhatsApp discussion.Ms Turley said the Skwawkbox article made  and defamatory allegations about her and impugned her honesty. I had not dishonestly joined the Community section of Unite and there was no reason to suspect me of being dishonest, she told the judge. I believed I was entitled to join it. She added: I am not dishonest and have not lied or sought to mislead. My reputation for honesty and integrity are of the utmost importance to me. They go to the root of who I am and why I am in public service. Ms Turley said in todayaposs statement: I am very pleased with today’s verdict, and to be able to say that I have won my libel action against Unite the Union and Skwawkbox. The judge found that that the article caused serious harm to my reputation and there were no reasonable grounds to suspect any form of dishonesty on my part. For Skwawkbox to have publicly accused me of this in their article was deeply damaging to my professional reputation and extremely hurtful.

story: NewsGovernments £, citizenship fee for children struck down as unlawfulThe charge was for registering a child as a citizen was branded "exorbitant" - as the application costs the Home Office just £ to processShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC NewsHome Secretary Priti Patel with Boris Johnson " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Government’s £, fee for registering children as British citizens has been struck down as unlawful by the High Court, in what has been described as a “landmark ruling.” The Project for the Registration of Children as British Citizensargued the exorbitant registration fee - for an application which costs the Home Office just £ to process - effectively removes childrenaposs entitlement to citizenship. In a judgment delivered on Thursday, Mr Justice Jay said that the fee was unlawful because the Home Office had failed to have regard to the best interests of children affected by the level of the fee. The PRCBC says that many children who are entitled to citizenship, having been born in the UK and lived here for their first  years, are prevented from applying because of the excessively high fee. The case, which was supported by Amnesty International UK, was brought on behalf of two children identied only as O who is  years old, and A, three, both of whom were born in the UK and have lived here their entire lives. The judge ruled that the regulations which set the fee are unlawful in that respect to the extent that they set the fee for registration applications brought by children at £,. He added that there was no evidence that the Home Office had identied where the best interests of children seeking registration lie, has begun to characterise those interests properlyhas identied that the level of fee creates practical dficulties for many. Mr Justice Jay said the evidence before the court showed that for a substantial number of children, a fee of £, is simply unaffordable, which made the children affected feel alienated, excluded, isolated, apossecond-bestapos, insecure and not fully assimilated into the culture and social fabric of the UK. The judge added that O and her mother could only afford the fee by taking steps which to my mind would be wholly unreasonable. Mr Justice Jay dismissed the PRCBCaposs argument that the level of the fee was unlawful because it renders a childaposs entitlement to British citizenship nugatory. But he said that he was referring that issue to be considered in the Supreme Courtthat court so advises. The judge also gave the Home Office permission to appeal against his ruling. In a statement after the ruling, Solange Valdez-Symonds, co-founder of the PRCBC, said: It is signicant that the court has recognised British citizenship is the right of these and thousands of children and that the consequences of blocking their registration rights is alienating and harmful. While that recognition is a great step forward, the fact remains that tens of thousands of British children are growing up in this country deprived of their rights to its citizenship, including by this shamelessly profiteering fee. For too long, children and their citizenship rights have not been respected. That must change. The Government should make an immediate start by ending the use of this fee to raise revenue for the Home Office.  Responding to the judgment, O - who told the court of her fear that her school friends would find out that she is not British like them - said: I am glad I got to tell the court my story. I was born in this country and have lived here all my le. I feel as British as any of my friends and itaposs not right that I am excluded from citizenship by a huge fee. I want to be able to do all the things my friends can. I donapost want to have to worry they will find out I donapost have a British passport and think that means I am not the same as them. Carol Bohmer, chair of the PRCBC, said: This is a landmark ruling. But the fight for justice for children born and growing up in the UK goes on. She added: The damage done to thousands of children is dreadful and still far from fully quantiable. So much more still needs to be done so that children, their parents and carers, know their citizenship rights and to ensure the many barriers to exercising these rights are removed, including this profit-making fee.

It wasn’t a feast of acquisition, because there was so little to get. Everything was still on the ration, or rarely found in the shops. Nor was there money to buy luxury food or goods anyway. Wages were low, and expectations the same. If you don’t believe me, look at photographs of people in those days. Slim, and not for fashion’s sake. Clothes were worn until they wore out, and then made into rag rugs. We had once-a-year chicken, raised behind the garden shed and its neck wrung by a neighbour. Despite wartime RAF service, my dad was too squeamish to do the job. Motherand I plucked it behind the scullery door, collecting the feathers in a brown paper carrier bag.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has unveiled the most radical Queenaposs Speech in a generation with measures to toughen up criminal justice, invest in the NHS and deliver on the peopleaposs priorities. The Prime Minister trumped Bills which will ensure the most serious violent offenders - including terrorists - serve longer prison terms after the London Bridge attack. A Royal Commission will be established to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the criminal justice process, and the Government will enshrine in law a commitment on NHS funding. Addressing MPs after the speech, Mr Johnson vowed that his Government would work flat out to deliver a new golden age for the UK, as he insisted his vision is for the long term. This is not a programme for one year or one parliament - it is a blueprint for the future of Britain, he said. But TUC general secretary Frances O’Grady sounded a note of caution - saying working people will want to check the small print before trusting this government’s promises. So what are the details in the small print  Weaposve had a look at  points you should know. Boris Johnson was been accused of rowing back on his promise to implement a £. minimum wage by  for everyone over the age of .It was the flagship policy announcement at the Tory conference, where Chancellor Sajid Javid proclaimed it would show the Tories are the workersapos party and help million workers.It is to be achieved by pegging the wage to two-thirds of median earnings, not % as it is now. But the small print of the Queenaposs Speech shows there is a sneaky get-out clause. It says the change to two-thirds of median earnings will only happen provided economic conditions allow. That is likely to prompt speculation thatthere is an economic downturn, the rise wonapost happen.Chi Onwurah, shadow business minister, told HuffPost UK: “In the very first moments of his new government Boris Johnson is already breaking promises he made during the election.. A shake-up of the entire constitution  The Queenaposs Speech plans a massive overhaul of Britainaposs constitution just a week after winning power. The Prime Minister announced that he would set up a new commission which could radically alter how Britain works. He will use the excuse of restoring trust in politics - even though he was widely considering to have undermined it during his time at No  so far. In the small print, the Commission promises to examine the broader aspects of the constitution in depth and develop proposals to restore trust in our institutions and in how our democracy operates. But the changes could prompt immediate fears that the Tory government was attempting to bolster its own power. The new unit could redraw constituency boundaries to reduce the number of MPs from  to , a move which could favour the Conservatives. He could also repeal the Fixed Term Parliaments Act meaning he could call an election when he wants to. There could be a move to repeal the Human Rights Act, replacing it with a bill of rights that could potentially lower protections. And in the wake of Mr Johnsonaposs Supreme Court loss, Britainaposs most senior judges could be made more accountable to Parliament - which could undermine the independence of the judiciary. Best for Britain chief executive Naomi Smith said: Johnsonaposs proposed constitution, democracy and rights commission should set alarm bells ringing for anyone who believes that Parliament must be able to act as a brake on a runaway government. We must be hyper-vigilant to any chipping away of the checks-and-balances that keep our democracy ing. No later flatly denied Supreme Court judges could become political appointees. . Britain could get new laws on treason  The small print of a law on espionage says the government will look at the case for updating treason laws. There is no further detail but it raises the spectre of new offences being allowed under laws that date back to Medieval times. MPs including Tory Tom Tugendhat and Labouraposs Khalid Mahmood have previously argued there is a case for updating the  Treason Act. Itaposs true that itaposs out of date. The last person to be tried for treason in the UK was in . But the Law Commission previously said treason law had ceased to be of contemporary relevance. And reviving it may prompt fears of a law that was killed off long ago coming back into being. . Workersapos rights pledges just arenapost clear yet Thereaposs a new Employment Bill which the Tories say will safeguard workersapos rights after Brexit .But the thing is, there isnapost enough detail on it yet to be clear about what those safeguards will be. The original Brexit Bill in October had promised that each time ministers make a new law in future, they would have to commit that in their view it doesnapost regress from EU workersapos rights. If they could not do so, they would have had to make a statement saying the new law might regress from EU workersapos rights. Thataposs now been dropped from the Brexit Bill. But it doesnapost yet, according to the Queenaposs Speech notes, appear in the new Employment Bill. Instead, the Queenaposs Speech makes a more general statement that the new Bill will protect and enhance workersapos rights as the UK leaves the EU, making Britain the best place in the world to work. Tim Roache, GMB General Secretary, said: “The Prime Minister claims he will protect and enhance workers’ rights but his record on keeping his promises leaves a lot to be desired. We’ll be holding him to account.  . People will be forced to show ID to vote   The Queenaposs Speech confirms measures will be implemented to force voters to show photo ID before being allowed to vote. Hundreds of people were denied their right to vote in last year’s local elections after ministers forced through a pilot scheme, despite warnings it could disenfranchise older voters and people from minority groups. The trial, which was held in eight council areas, resulted in  people being turned away. That was despite official figures showing there were just eight allegations of people lying about who they are at a polling station - known as personation - in . That was down from  in ,  in ,  in  and  in , the Electoral Commission figures show. The Queenaposs Speech says people without an approved form of photographic ID will be able to request an identity document. But campaigners say the move will hit low-income and vulnerable voters less likely to have the right paperwork. There are other measures too that critics say could benefit the Tories - letting ex-pats vote for leand shaking up constituency boundaries. . Thereaposs still no solution for social care The Queenaposs Speech promises to begin urgent work on a cross-party solution to social care. But despite Boris Johnson saying he had a plan ready to go, there is no detail - apart from a commitment that no one will have to sell their home.Dan Scorer of the learning disability charity Mencap said: Cross party consensus is a good idea, but they need to get on with it. The extra £ billion sounds a lot, but is nowhere near enough Dr Jenner Dixon chief executive of the Health Foundation said: With growing numbers of people unable to access the care they need, there is no time to waste. Fundamental reform of social care should be the immediate priority - the government must now grasp the nettle. Jeremy Hughes, Chief Executive at Alzheimer’s Society, said “The state of dementia care is in crisis. The Prime Minister committed to end the injustice when he met Barbara Windsor. Where’s the action  Jonathan Blades of the MS Society said: “It’s been years since we were first promised a plan on how to fix our failing social care system, and we’re still in the dark.
